body:
**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

it is related to #91 to the degree that we'd be concerned with what's in the ``__init__.py``, but this specific issue is more about the discussion in issue #72.   Seems like I left off with, "sure, I don't mind getting it to ignore ``__init__.py``".     

But given the proposals in #91, it seems like there's a choice whether we decide to ignore ``__init__.py``, or we change Alembic to actually import the versions directory more like a package - even though #91 is more about each version as a package, seems like we should think about what an ``__init__.py`` means here.   right now we pull in the version files using ``imp.load_source()`` on each file individually.

The #91 change isn't happening on my end anytime soon, whereas just ignoring ``__init__.py`` is a quick fix.

**Anonymous wrote:**

Exact, my feature request is more about the discussion in #72 and I don't really need what's described in #91 - seems strange to me to have so much code in a migration script.

I'm in favor of ignoring the `__init__.py` file for now, but the real question is: should it be ignored silently?

Actually, since you don't generate an `__init__.py` by default, there's no incentive to put code there. So, if the user choose to add one, we can assume he knows what it does and just ignore the  `__init__.py` file silently. But, like I said before, the migrations scripts will not be packaged by default in this setup.

I would prefer the `__init__.py` file to be there by default so we don't forget to package the versions files, but I guess we should warn the user that he should not add code in the `__init__.py` file, maybe by putting a big uppercase warning comment in the `__init__.py` file?

Or maybe this `__init__.py` file should just be the new `env.py`?

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

I don't see the need for env.py to move like that, it's a separate and very specific concern versus the environment in which migration files run.   an ``__init__.py`` would theoretically include helpers that migration scripts use but really, I put those helpers in my application elsewhere (usually in myapp/model/migration/).

at the moment the thinking is just that we'll let ``__init__.py`` be there so as to take advantage of a behavioral artifact of distutils, but otherwise it's a do-nothing file.   Im sure people will start asking for it to be functional at some point, but we can address that later.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

oh but putting it there anyway, I'm a little hesitant for that..since even having it there feels like a hack to me.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

but maybe im being too purist

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

and yeah, us putting it there means we can put a message, "alembic ignores this file!" inside of it

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* added labels: **versioning model**

**techno techne wrote:**

It would be nice if there were a specific warning explaining that there shouldn't be an `__init__.py` in this directory, if you put one in there. I was just very confused (my IDE had created this file automatically at some point). If you didn't do this on purpose, it's a confusing error message.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

counterpoint, it would be nice if your IDE didn't produce `__init__.py` files in directories without being asked :)

**techno techne wrote:**

Yes, I anticipated that. But it's an exceptionally good IDE, with generally reasonable assumptions (PyCharm). It didn't do this out of nowhere, it's because I used one of its refactoring gestures to move my `migrations` directory. That's when the `__init__.py` was created.

The point isn't my IDE. The point is that it's reasonable to assume that a folder of Python modules could also be made into a Python package by adding an `__init__.py`. In most cases, this will not break things. So people (or IDEs) might do it, and maybe it'd be good to correct their error fast.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

anyway, the plan on this issue is to ignore the file.   i dont see a need to warn about it.

**techno techne wrote:**

OK, that's even better. I read "at the moment the thinking is just that we'll let __init__.py be there" and thought you meant this issue would not be addressed in any way... should have read the whole comment and the rest of the thread. Thanks, sorry to waste your time!

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

I still could use a PR with the feature + test to make this easier :) otherwise this is sorta far down the list atm.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- ignore __init__.py in versions directory, fixes #95.


â†’ 590132c52e9f

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **status** to closed

issue.title: Allow revisions to access other revisions

repository.name: alembic
repository.description: A database migrations tool for SQLAlchemy.

issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by Derek Harland ([@donkopotamus](https://github.com/donkopotamus))**

In my work its often the case that a particular revision would like to be able to access variables or call functions in another revision.

For example, consider a revision `db_09` that alters the definition of a view `SomeView` that was previously defined in `db_08`.  It would be nice to be able to have access to this previous definition somehow.  For example, supposing we have an class `db_view` that can create/drop itself, then we'd like to be able to do something like:

```python
# db_08
some_view = db_view(â€¦)

def upgrade():
    some_view.create()

def downgrade():
    some_view.drop()

```
and
```python
# db_09
some_view = db_view(â€¦)

def upgrade():
    import db_08

    # drop old definition, then create new version
    db_08.some_view.drop()
    some_view.create()

def downgrade():
    # drop newer definition, create old version
    some_view.drop()
    db_08.some_view.create()
```

More generally, it would be nice for `db_09` to be able to find the latest version prior to it that has a definition for `some_view` to help with the downgrade function â€¦ without having to know it was created in `db_03` for example.

Another time we may need this sort of functionality is when we alter a table that a view may depend on.  We may need to drop the current view definition before altering the table and then restoring the view.  (Another approach to this particular problem is to query the database to find all dependencies of the table (and their dependencies), grab their definitions and store for replay later.  But this is not really possible if you are in `--sql` mode)

Currently for example my code does something like:

- beside the versions directory there is a `details` directory

    - this contains the real upgrade/downgrade code for every version

    - in a sense this is an implementation of issue #91

- a version `XXX.py` in the `versions/` directory just calls its matching `details.XXX.upgrade/downgrade`

- supporting functions then traverse the details submodules and allow us to get hold of the current and previous definitions of all views/procedures/functions etc.  (And allow us to store their definitions as plain txt files also)
